title: Why React 19 Will Change Everything
content: React 19 introduces major updates that simplify server components and suspense. In this post, we’ll explore what these changes mean for both beginners and advanced devs. The Server Actions API is a huge deal, enabling you to write backend logic inline with UI components. That, combined with enhanced streaming and partial hydration, is setting a new benchmark.
author: ashutosh

title: The Cleanest Way to Structure a Full Stack App
content: Let’s talk folders, service layers, types, and everything in between. Full stack apps can easily get messy. The cleanest structure I’ve found involves separating your app into core, domain, and feature modules. Alongside, use tools like Zod for validation, Prisma for DB access, and tRPC or REST for API access. Codegen and layered architecture help massively here.
author: devdude

title: Proof of Work vs Proof of Stake: Beginner Friendly Breakdown
content: This guide simplifies the two most important consensus mechanisms. Proof of Work relies on computational power to mine blocks — think Bitcoin. Proof of Stake, on the other hand, uses economic staking to secure the network — think Ethereum post-merge. We’ll explore real-world analogies, security trade-offs, and future trends in consensus design.
author: chainqueen

title: Debugging with AI: A Complete Workflow
content: Using GitHub Copilot, ChatGPT, and Cursor to squash bugs efficiently is the new standard. This post walks through how to isolate problems, generate suggestions, and even write tests using AI tools. You'll be surprised how much faster you debug with this workflow.
author: bughunter

title: Monorepo Magic with Turbo, PNPM, and NX
content: Tired of messy codebases? Learn how monorepos using Turborepo, PNPM workspaces, and NX help scale large apps. We'll explore dependency graphing, caching, and how to maintain blazing fast CI/CD.
author: monomaster

title: How to Build Your Own DevBuzz in 3 Days
content: Inspired by Hacker News, this post outlines how to bootstrap a clone from scratch using Next.js, Prisma, shadcn/ui, and custom auth. Includes structure, routing, styling, and deployment tips.
author: ashutosh

title: Top 10 TypeScript Tips for 2025
content: Here are the most useful tricks every TypeScript developer should know — from conditional types to template literal types, and real-world use of `satisfies` and `infer`. These will level up your DX immediately.
author: tsguru

title: Tailwind CSS v4 — What’s New?
content: Tailwind 4.0 brings design tokens, CSS variables, improved dark mode support, and faster build times. This post goes over all the changes and how to migrate your existing project.
author: csswizard

title: A Step-by-Step Guide to Prisma + PostgreSQL
content: Learn how to set up a production-ready PostgreSQL database with Prisma, including schema design, relationships, migrations, and seed data. Great for new full-stack devs.
author: dbdoc

title: Mastering React Server Components
content: Server components are the future of React. This post covers the why, when, and how of RSCs, including loading patterns, suspense boundaries, and working with server-only logic.
author: reactpro

title: Unlocking the Power of Zod for Runtime Safety
content: Zod lets you enforce validation at runtime with TypeScript. This guide walks you through real-world schemas, error handling, and combining with React forms.
author: typehero

title: The Case for Vanilla JavaScript in 2025
content: Frameworks are great, but sometimes native JavaScript is the simplest, cleanest tool. This post makes a strong case with examples for ditching React in small projects.
author: nostalgicdev

title: How to Deploy a Next.js App in 2 Minutes
content: Need a quick deployment pipeline? This guide walks you through deploying a Next.js app to Vercel with env vars, preview branches, and CI/CD in 2 minutes flat.
author: fastdeploy

title: Rate Limiting Your API the Right Way
content: Protect your app from abuse by learning how to add IP-based and token-based rate limiting using libraries like `express-rate-limit`, Redis, and middleware guards.
author: secureapi

title: An Intro to shadcn/ui
content: This post introduces the shadcn/ui component system — how it's different from component libraries, how to install and customize, and why it blends so well with Tailwind.
author: uimaster

title: Understanding Server Actions in Next.js 15
content: Next.js 15 introduces server actions. Learn how to use them for mutation logic, type-safe form handling, and how they replace API routes in many cases.
author: nextnerd

title: How Cursor Made Me 5x Faster at Debugging
content: Cursor.dev is an AI coding editor built on VS Code. Here's how it changed my workflow for the better — from autocomplete to debugging entire files with one prompt.
author: aipilot

title: AI Prompt Engineering for Developers
content: Prompt engineering is a skill every dev should master in 2025. Learn how to write effective prompts, chain requests, and build prompt-based tools inside your apps.
author: prompter

title: The Hidden Cost of Over-Engineering
content: Too many abstractions can kill productivity. This post outlines examples of over-engineered systems and how to identify unnecessary complexity in your stack.
author: simplicityfirst

title: Web3 UX Sucks — Here's How We Can Fix It
content: Let’s face it — Web3 onboarding and wallets are painful. Here are 5 product and developer solutions to improve UX in dApps, from gasless flows to session keys.
author: onchainuser
